title: 115_s848
content: The Act titled "Reigniting Opportunity for Innovators Act" allows for loan deferment and cancellation for small business startup founders and employees. The "Reigniting Opportunity for Innovators Act" allows loan deferment without interest accrual for small business startup founders and employees under certain conditions. The paragraph outlines the conditions for loan deferment for small business startup founders and employees, including limitations on the period of deferment and definitions of key terms. Loan cancellation for founders and employees of small business startups in distressed areas is outlined in the amendment to Section 455 of the Higher Education Act of 1965. The Secretary is required to cancel the balance of interest and principal due for qualifying small business startup borrowers approved by a small business development center. Loan cancellation is available for founders and full-time employees of small business startups in distressed areas who meet certain criteria. This includes being approved for loan cancellation by a small business development center and starting employment within a specific timeframe. Loan cancellation is available for founders and full-time employees of small business startups in distressed areas who meet specific criteria. This includes establishing the startup, making 24 monthly payments on an eligible Federal Direct Loan, and being approved by a small business development center within 10 years of establishment. The Secretary will cancel a maximum of loans under this program. Under this program, a borrower can have up to $20,000 of their loan obligation cancelled on eligible Federal Direct Loans. Payments must be made monthly after the enactment of this program. Borrowers cannot receive benefits from both this program and other specified sections. The term "distressed area" is defined as per the Small Business Act. The Small Business Act defines terms like 'eligible Federal Direct Loan', 'founder', 'full-time employee', and 'small business startup'. The Small Business Act (15 U.S.C. 648(o)(3)) is further amended in Title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 1070a et seq.) to make conforming amendments to various sections related to subsections of section 455. SEC. 3. SMALL BUSINESS DEVELOPMENT CENTERS. Section 21 of the Small Business Act is amended to include certifying small business startups and approving loan deferment or cancellation for founders and employees. Additionally, a new section is added for the deferment or cancellation of certain loans in distressed areas. The term 'low-income community' is defined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The term 'eligible Federal Direct Loan' is defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965. The terms 'founder' and 'full-time employee' for a small business startup are defined by the Administrator. A 'small business startup' is a business that has been in existence for not more than 3 years when applying. Small business development centers can assist with eligible purposes. Small business development centers can certify and approve Federal Direct Loan deferment or cancellation for small business startups. To be certified, a startup must submit a 5-year business plan and employee information to the center. The Administrator will publish a list of distressed areas on the Administration's website. Small business startups can apply for loan deferment for founders and full-time employees through small business development centers by submitting a business plan and employee details. A borrower of an eligible Federal Direct Loan must submit an application to a small business development center with required information. The center will approve loan deferment if the borrower is a founder or full-time employee of a certified small business startup. Loan cancellation for founders and full-time employees of a small business startup in a distressed area requires an application with necessary information to be submitted to a small business development center for approval. The borrower must have made 24 monthly payments on the Federal Direct Loan to be eligible for loan cancellation. The small business development center will approve the borrower if they are employed by a small business startup in a distressed area. The borrower must have been employed by a small business startup in a distressed area for 5 to 10 years to be eligible for loan cancellation. The borrower must have been employed by a small business startup in a distressed area for 5 to 10 years to be eligible for loan cancellation within 5 years of establishment.
